messageBody:
> > +1 Then the trick becomes naming the test well.
>
> On that note, what conventions does everyone here use to name their test
> methods? For this example, mine would look like:
>
> test_push_emptyStack()
> test_push_stackWith1Element()
> test_push_fullStack()
> test_push_nullElement()
>
> in other words,
> "test" + /primary/ method under test + scenario description
>
> I've also considered names that indicate whether an exception is
> expected, such as
>
> test_push_nullElement_throwsIAX() // IllegalArgumentException
>
> but I've rejected this convention for aesthetic reasons.


Aside from the underscores (which Sun says are not "according to Hoyle"[1])
my convention broadly similiar. Here are some samples from my current test
suite

tests for a class named AddElementChange (which creates a change packet for
adding an element)
- testAddToRoot()
- testAddElementTwice()
- testAddElementToChildFolder()
- testAddElementExceptions()
- testAddElementChangesCBM()

most of these are self evident. In my parlance anything test method that
ends with Exceptions is testing how the method behaves with bad data (null,
-1, etc). The last test is there to test the underlying system - does the
Add actually change the underlying model. Strictly this is more an
integration test than a unit test. But I'm happy to mix the two a bit.

Cheers
Mark

[1] http://www.bartleby.com/59/4/accordingtoh.html
